unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked if online learning is actually worth it in India, especially with all these new EdTech companies popping up. I’ll share my experience, as someone who's seen both sides – the traditional classroom and the digital learning platform.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked if online learning is actually worth it in India, especially with all these new EdTech companies popping up. I will share my experience, as someone who has seen both sides – the traditional classroom and the digital learning platform.

unnormalised: I grew up in a small town, you know, where access to quality education wasn't exactly abundant. The local school was okay, but the teachers were often overworked, and the resources were limited. Getting extra tuition meant travelling to a bigger city, which wasn't feasible for my family. That's where online learning came in. My parents enrolled me in a course on Byju's for mathematics in Class 10. Honestly, I was skeptical at first. I thought, how can learning happen through a screen? But I was pleasantly surprised. The video lectures were engaging, and the interactive quizzes helped me understand concepts better. The best part was, I could learn at my own pace. If I didn't understand something, I could just rewind and watch it again. That's something you can't do in a classroom. My score in maths improved from 60% in the previous year to 85% in the board exams.

My score in maths improved from sixty percent in the previous year to eighty five percent in the board exams.

unnormalised: Then came college. I secured admission at a decent engineering college but the subjects felt very fast paced. It was difficult to keep up with the lectures, so I ended up looking up many topics from NPTEL and Coursera. The online lectures taught me the concepts in a lot more depth, and I could rewind and replay topics I did not follow easily. There was no such facility in physical classrooms. My grades improved significantly.

unnormalised: I think the key is to be disciplined. It's easy to get distracted when you're learning from home, but if you can create a structured study schedule and stick to it, online learning can be incredibly effective. Some platforms also have doubt-clearing sessions, which can be really helpful. Many of my friends are doing courses on Unacademy and Vedantu, and they seem to be benefiting from them as well.

It is easy to get distracted when you are learning from home, but if you can create a structured study schedule and stick to it, online learning can be incredibly effective. Some platforms also have doubt-clearing sessions, which can be really helpful. Many of my friends are doing courses on Unacademy and Vedantu, and they seem to be benefiting from them as well.

unnormalised: Of course, there are drawbacks. The lack of face-to-face interaction can be isolating for some people. And you need a good internet connection, which can be a challenge in some parts of India. I remember there were times when I missed a class because of power cuts or internet outages. It is also easy to get distracted by youtube and social media while you're studying at home, so you need to actively fight distractions.

It is also easy to get distracted by youtube and social media while you are studying at home, so you need to actively fight distractions.

unnormalised: Also, not all online courses are created equal. Some are just glorified video recordings with no interaction or support. So, it's important to do your research and choose a reputable platform. Check reviews, talk to other students, and see if they offer a free trial before committing to a course.

unnormalised: One other thing to consider is the cost. While some online courses are free, others can be quite expensive, sometimes even more expensive than traditional tuition. Think about your budget, and whether you really need that particular course before enrolling.

unnormalised: Overall, I think online learning has a lot of potential, especially in a country like India where access to quality education is not always guaranteed. It's not a perfect solution, but it can be a valuable tool for supplementing traditional learning, upskilling, and pursuing your passions. Just remember to be disciplined, do your research, and choose a platform that fits your needs and budget. And honestly, if it helped me go from a small town school to a decent engineering college and improved my marks, then it can do wonders for others too.
